body:
In GitLab by @asottile on Jun 26, 2018, 09:25

Note that this is due to a bug in `flake8-mutable` (which seems unmaintained).  There's [an open PR](https://github.com/ebeweber/flake8-mutable/pull/20) to fix this.

In GitLab by @sigmavirus24 on Oct 20, 2018, 10:03

closed

In GitLab by @sambrightman on Feb 23, 2019, 19:29

Was this closed in favour of another issue? It seems like quite a common problem: you have many plugins installed, and want to enable some violations that are off-by-default. Doing so forces you to list all prefixes of all plugins, and remember to do that going forward for new plugins.

In GitLab by @asottile on Feb 23, 2019, 19:45

I believe this was closed because the code which wasn't being enabled by default is due to a bug in `flake8-mutable`

That said, I don't think it's possible for flake8 the framework to know all of the codes that could be produced by plugins to enable them all (since a plugin doesn't necessarily list the codes they produce in their entrypoint, ala flake8-mutable).

In GitLab by @sambrightman on Feb 24, 2019, 04:18

`flake8-mutable` was just used as an example - the ticket is about the general problem. It feels like an option which non-exclusively selects would be useful. That would cover most of the use-case without having to know all of the codes a plugin provides. It would be good if they could all be known - I often have tried to find a way to list available codes - but presumably that would have to be baked-in to the API.

In GitLab by @asottile on Feb 24, 2019, 09:03

Right, but I don't think it's possible. 

Take flake8-mutable for example, this is all the information we have from that plugin from the framework side: https://github.com/ebeweber/flake8-mutable/blob/4e0394e61841edff876301a98f6153805ecc4b9b/setup.py#L21

At runtime, any plugin _could_ produce any code -- independent of what they've declared they will produce

In GitLab by @sambrightman on Feb 24, 2019, 12:56

Exactly: you could imagine an API where it would be possible via registration of codes but it's not possible now. However, the described problem is neither about `flake8-mutable` nor really listing all codes. It is about enabling default-disabled codes without having to explicitly list all other codes.

*That* seems like it is possible. My suggestion is having something like `extend-select` (not the best name) which selects without being exclusive.

In GitLab by @asottile on Feb 24, 2019, 12:58

"enabling all default-ignored things" is already possible via `ignore=` (with no value).

I believe what you're asking for is "enable things which aren't registered" which is arguably a bug in the plugins in question

In GitLab by @asottile on Feb 24, 2019, 13:00

fwiw, `extend-select` is already a proposed and accepted feature request, though there is not yet an implementation: #365

In GitLab by @sambrightman on Feb 24, 2019, 14:05

The aim is not necessarily to enable *all* default-ignored things. `ignore=` does not seem to help here: it prevents ignoring anything else and I don't believe it would enable default-disabled codes from plugins.

* I have an `ignore` list for `flake8` core and various plugins.
* I have a plugin that leaves some codes disabled by default (I don't know enough about `flake8` to say whether it is a bug, but it appears to be both intentional, common practice and useful).
* I want to keep my `ignore` list and add some or all of the disabled codes.
* using `select` requires listing everything, which is awkward both now and for maintenance.
* using `ignore=` enables absolutely everything but (possibly?) doesn't help with my plugin's default-disabled codes.

I think the original reporter probably had the same scenario in mind, just misunderstood what was wrong with a particular code. I've encountered similar with multiple plugins which documented their off-by-default codes and suggested using `select` to enable them.

#365 possibly covers this use-case. It is hard to tell from the description though. If the intention is to literally add to the `select` list, I don't think it will help for the reasons above.
